paragraphs.text:
%md

# Oracle Machine Learning for Python - Data Selection and Manipulation

***Oracle Machine Learning for Python*** (OML4Py), a component of Oracle Machine Learning, makes the open source Python scripting language and environment ready for the enterprise and big data. Designed for problems involving both large and small volumes of data, Oracle Machine Learning for Python integrates Python with Oracle Autonomous Database, allowing users to execute Python commands and scripts for statistical, machine learning, and graphical analyses on database tables and views using Python syntax. Many familiar Python functions are overloaded and translate Python functions into SQL for in-database execution, as well as new automated machine learning capabilities.

In this notebook, we highlight features of the transparency layer involving data selection and manipulation.

Copyright (c) 2020 Oracle Corporation                             
###### [The Universal Permissive License (UPL), Version 1.0](https://oss.oracle.com/licenses/upl/)
---

msg.data:
Oracle Machine Learning for Python - Data Selection and Manipulation

Oracle Machine Learning for Python (OML4Py), a component of Oracle Machine Learning, makes the open source Python scripting language and environment ready for the enterprise and big data. Designed for problems involving both large and small volumes of data, Oracle Machine Learning for Python integrates Python with Oracle Autonomous Database, allowing users to execute Python commands and scripts for statistical, machine learning, and graphical analyses on database tables and views using Python syntax. Many familiar Python functions are overloaded and translate Python functions into SQL for in-database execution, as well as new automated machine learning capabilities.

In this notebook, we highlight features of the transparency layer involving data selection and manipulation.

Copyright (c) 2020 Oracle Corporation

The Universal Permissive License (UPL), Version 1.0

paragraphs.text:
%md

## Import libraries supporting OML4Py and create data table

To use OML4Py, first import the package ***oml***. 

Users can get online help using Python's help function and specifying the function of interest.

msg.data:
Import libraries supporting OML4Py and create data table

To use OML4Py, first import the package oml.

Users can get online help using Python's help function and specifying the function of interest.

paragraphs.title: Import libraries and set display options
paragraphs.text:
%python

import warnings
warnings.filterwarnings('ignore')

import pandas as pd
import oml

pd.set_option('display.max_rows', 500)
pd.set_option('display.max_columns', 500)
pd.set_option('display.width', 1000)

paragraphs.title: Create a temporary table for the IRIS data
paragraphs.text:
%python

from sklearn.datasets import load_iris
import pandas as pd

iris = load_iris()

x = pd.DataFrame(iris.data, columns = ['SEPAL_LENGTH','SEPAL_WIDTH', 'PETAL_LENGTH','PETAL_WIDTH'])
y = pd.DataFrame(list(map(lambda x: {0: 'setosa', 1: 'versicolor', 2:'virginica'}[x], iris.target)), 
                 columns = ['SPECIES'])
z = pd.concat([x, y], axis=1)

IRIS_TMP = oml.push(z)

%md
## Select table columns using proxy object IRIS_TMP

msg.data: Select table columns using proxy object IRIS_TMP

paragraphs.title: Select specific columns by name
paragraphs.text:
%python

IRIS_projected1 = IRIS_TMP[:, ["SEPAL_LENGTH", "PETAL_LENGTH"]]
IRIS_projected1.head(3)

msg.data:
SEPAL_LENGTH  PETAL_LENGTH
0           4.6             1
1           5.1             3
2           6.0             4

paragraphs.title: Select specific columns by index range
paragraphs.text:
%python

IRIS_projected2 = IRIS_TMP[:, 1:4]
IRIS_projected2.head(3)

msg.data:
SEPAL_WIDTH  PETAL_LENGTH  PETAL_WIDTH
0          3.6             1          0.2
1          2.5             3          1.1
2          2.2             4          1.0

paragraphs.title: Select specific columns by data type
paragraphs.text:
%python

IRIS_projected3 = IRIS_TMP.select_types(include=[oml.String])
IRIS_projected3.head(3)

msg.data:
SPECIES
0      setosa
1  versicolor
2  versicolor

paragraphs.text:
%md

## Select table rows using proxy object IRIS_TMP

* select sepal length and petal length where petal length is less than 1.5
* select all rows in which petal length is less than 1.5 or sepal length is 5.0, using the AND and OR conditions in filtering
* select all rows in which petal length is less than 1.5 and sepal length is larger than 5.0

msg.data:
Select table rows using proxy object IRIS_TMP

  • select sepal length and petal length where petal length is less than 1.5
  • select all rows in which petal length is less than 1.5 or sepal length is 5.0, using the AND and OR conditions in filtering
  • select all rows in which petal length is less than 1.5 and sepal length is larger than 5.0

paragraphs.title: Simple row selection
paragraphs.text:
%python

IRIS_filtered1 = IRIS_TMP[IRIS_TMP["PETAL_LENGTH"] < 1.5, 
                                  ["SEPAL_LENGTH", "PETAL_LENGTH"]]
print("Length: ", len(IRIS_filtered1))
IRIS_filtered1.head(3)

msg.data:
Length:  24
   SEPAL_LENGTH  PETAL_LENGTH
0           4.6           1.0
1           4.3           1.1
2           5.8           1.2

paragraphs.title: Compound row selection with 'or'
paragraphs.text:
%python

IRIS_filtered2 = IRIS_TMP[(IRIS_TMP["PETAL_LENGTH"] < 1.5) | 
                          (IRIS_TMP["SEPAL_LENGTH"] == 5.0), :]
print("Length: ", len(IRIS_filtered2))
IRIS_filtered2.head(3)

msg.data:
Length:  30
   SEPAL_LENGTH  SEPAL_WIDTH  PETAL_LENGTH  PETAL_WIDTH SPECIES
0           4.6          3.6           1.0          0.2  setosa
1           4.3          3.0           1.1          0.1  setosa
2           5.8          4.0           1.2          0.2  setosa

paragraphs.title: Compound row selection with 'and'
paragraphs.text:
%python

IRIS_filtered3 = IRIS_TMP[(IRIS_TMP["PETAL_LENGTH"] < 1.5) & 
                          (IRIS_TMP["SEPAL_LENGTH"] > 5.0), :]
print("Length: ", len(IRIS_filtered3))
IRIS_filtered3.head(4)

msg.data:
Length:  7
   SEPAL_LENGTH  SEPAL_WIDTH  PETAL_LENGTH  PETAL_WIDTH SPECIES
0           5.8          4.0           1.2          0.2  setosa
1           5.5          3.5           1.3          0.2  setosa
2           5.4          3.9           1.3          0.4  setosa
3           5.2          3.4           1.4          0.2  setosa

paragraphs.text:
%md

# Use Pandas DataFrame objects

Let's explore operations involving Pandas DataFrames.

We'll start by creating a temporary table from a Pandas DataFrame and use the ***append*** function. First, append an oml.Float series object to another, then append an oml.DataFrame object to another.

msg.data:
Use Pandas DataFrame objects

Let's explore operations involving Pandas DataFrames.

We'll start by creating a temporary table from a Pandas DataFrame and use the append function. First, append an oml.Float series object to another, then append an oml.DataFrame object to another.

paragraphs.title: Create demo data in temporary table
paragraphs.text:
%python

my_df = pd.DataFrame({"id" : [1, 2, 3, 4, 5],
                      "val" : ["a", "b", "c", "d", "e"],
                      "ch" : ["p", "q", "r", "a", "b"],
                      "num" : [4, 3, 6.7, 7.2, 5]})
MY_DF = oml.push(my_df)

print (my_df.dtypes)

num1 = MY_DF['id']
num2 = MY_DF['num']
num1.append(num2)

msg.data:
id       int64
val     object
ch      object
num    float64
dtype: object
[1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 4, 3, 6.7, 7.2, 5]

paragraphs.title: Using append( )
paragraphs.text:
%python

x = MY_DF[['id', 'val']] 
y = MY_DF[['num', 'ch']] 

print("Types x:\n", x.dtypes)
print("Types y:\n", y.dtypes)

x.append(y)

msg.data:
Types x:
 id       <class 'oml.core.float.Float'>
val    <class 'oml.core.string.String'>
dtype: object
Types y:
 num      <class 'oml.core.float.Float'>
ch     <class 'oml.core.string.String'>
dtype: object
    id val
0  1.0   a
1  2.0   b
2  3.0   c
3  4.0   d
4  5.0   e
5  4.0   p
6  3.0   q
7  6.7   r
8  7.2   a
9  5.0   b

paragraphs.text:
%md

Next, try a few examples using the ***concat*** function.

* create two oml.DataFrame objects and combine the objects column-wise
* create an oml.Float object with the rounded exponential of two times the values in the num column of the oml_frame object, then concatenate it with the oml.DataFrame object y using a new column name
* concatenate object x with multiple objects and turn on automatic name conflict resolution
* concatenate multiple OML data objects and perform customized renaming

msg.data:
Next, try a few examples using the concat function.

  • create two oml.DataFrame objects and combine the objects column-wise
  • create an oml.Float object with the rounded exponential of two times the values in the num column of the oml_frame object, then concatenate it with the oml.DataFrame object y using a new column name
  • concatenate object x with multiple objects and turn on automatic name conflict resolution
  • concatenate multiple OML data objects and perform customized renaming

paragraphs.title: Column-wise concatentation
paragraphs.text:
%python

from collections import OrderedDict

x = MY_DF[['id', 'val']]
y = MY_DF[['num', 'ch']]
x.concat(y)

msg.data:
id val  num ch
0   1   a  4.0  p
1   2   b  3.0  q
2   3   c  6.7  r
3   4   d  7.2  a
4   5   e  5.0  b

paragraphs.title: Concatenate new column
paragraphs.text:
%python

w = (MY_DF['num']*2).exp().round(decimals=2)
y.concat({'round(exp(2*num))':w})

paragraphs.title: Concatenate columns with name resolution
paragraphs.text:
%python

z = MY_DF[:,'id']
x.concat([z, w, y], auto_name=True)

paragraphs.title: Concatename with renaming
paragraphs.text:
%python

x.concat(OrderedDict([('ID',z), ('round(exp(2*num))',w), ('New_',y)]))

%md

Next, explore merging data using ***merge***. Perform:

* cross join
* left outer join
* right outer join

msg.data:
Next, explore merging data using merge. Perform:

  • cross join
  • left outer join
  • right outer join

paragraphs.title: Cross join
paragraphs.text:
%python

x = MY_DF[['id', 'val']]
y = MY_DF[['num', 'ch']]

z = x.merge(y)
z

paragraphs.title: Left outer join
paragraphs.text:
%python

x.head(4).merge(other=MY_DF[['id', 'num']], on="id", suffixes=['.l','.r'])

paragraphs.title: Right outer join
paragraphs.text:
%python

x.merge(other=y, left_on="id", right_on="num", how="right")

msg.data:
id_l val_l  num_r ch_r
0   3.0     c    3.0    q
1   4.0     d    4.0    p
2   5.0     e    5.0    b
3   NaN  None    6.7    r
4   NaN  None    7.2    a

paragraphs.text:
%md

Next, try the drop functonality with ***dropna***, ***drop_duplicates***, and ***drop***:

* drop rows with any missing values
* drop rows in which all column values are missing
* drop rows in which any numeric column values are missing
* drop duplicate rows
* drop rows that have the same value in column 'string1' and 'string2'
* drop column 'string2'

msg.data:
Next, try the drop functonality with dropna, drop_duplicates, and drop:

  • drop rows with any missing values
  • drop rows in which all column values are missing
  • drop rows in which any numeric column values are missing
  • drop duplicate rows
  • drop rows that have the same value in column 'string1' and 'string2'
  • drop column 'string2'

paragraphs.title: Create demo data
paragraphs.text:
%python

my_df2 = pd.DataFrame({'numeric': [1, 1.4, -4, -4, 5.432, None, None],
                   'string1' : [None, None, 'a', 'a', 'a', 'b', None],
                   'string2': ['x', None, 'z', 'z', 'z', 'x', None]})
MY_DF2 = oml.push(my_df2, dbtypes = {'numeric': 'BINARY_DOUBLE',
                                     'string1':'CHAR(1)', 
                                     'string2':'CHAR(1)'})
MY_DF2

msg.data:
numeric string1 string2
0    1.400    None    None
1      NaN    None    None
2    1.000    None       x
3      NaN       b       x
4   -4.000       a       z
5   -4.000       a       z
6    5.432       a       z

paragraphs.title: Drop rows with any missing values
paragraphs.text:
%python

MY_DF2.dropna(how='any')

msg.data:
numeric string1 string2
0   -4.000       a       z
1   -4.000       a       z
2    5.432       a       z

paragraphs.title: Drop rows where all column values missing
paragraphs.text:
%python

MY_DF2.dropna(how='all')

msg.data:
numeric string1 string2
0    1.400    None    None
1    1.000    None       x
2      NaN       b       x
3   -4.000       a       z
4   -4.000       a       z
5    5.432       a       z

paragraphs.title: Drop rows with any missing numeric values
paragraphs.text:
%python

MY_DF2.dropna(how='any', subset=['numeric'])

msg.data:
numeric string1 string2
0    1.400    None    None
1    1.000    None       x
2   -4.000       a       z
3   -4.000       a       z
4    5.432       a       z

paragraphs.title: Drop duplicate rows
paragraphs.text:
%python

MY_DF2.drop_duplicates()

msg.data:
numeric string1 string2
0    5.432       a       z
1    1.000    None       x
2      NaN       b       x
3   -4.000       a       z
4    1.400    None    None
5      NaN    None    None

paragraphs.title: Drop rows with same value in named columns
paragraphs.text:
%python

MY_DF2.drop_duplicates(subset=['string1', 'string2'])

msg.data:
numeric string1 string2
0     -4.0       a       z
1      1.4    None    None
2      1.0    None       x
3      NaN       b       x

paragraphs.title: Drop specific column
paragraphs.text:
%python

MY_DF2.drop('string2')

msg.data:
numeric string1
0    1.400    None
1      NaN    None
2    1.000    None
3      NaN       b
4   -4.000       a
5   -4.000       a
6    5.432       a

paragraphs.text:
%md

Next, explore the ***split*** and ***KFold*** function using the *digits* data set. After creating an OML DataFrame proxy object for the *digits* data set,

* split the data into 20% and 80% samples
* split the data into four sets of 25% each
* perform stratification on the target column
* verify that the stratified sampling generates splits in which all of the different categories of digits (digits 0~9) are present in each split
* hash on the target column
* verify that the different categories of digits (digits 0~9) are present in only one of the splits generated by hashing on the category column
* split the data randomly into 4 consecutive folds

msg.data:
Next, explore the split and KFold function using the digits data set. After creating an OML DataFrame proxy object for the digits data set,

  • split the data into 20% and 80% samples
  • split the data into four sets of 25% each
  • perform stratification on the target column
  • verify that the stratified sampling generates splits in which all of the different categories of digits (digits 0~9) are present in each split
  • hash on the target column
  • verify that the different categories of digits (digits 0~9) are present in only one of the splits generated by hashing on the category column
  • split the data randomly into 4 consecutive folds

paragraphs.title: Create demo data as temporary table
paragraphs.text:
%python

import pandas as pd
from sklearn.datasets import load_digits

digits = load_digits()
pd_digits = pd.DataFrame(digits.data,
                         columns=['IMG'+str(i) for i in
                         range(digits['data'].shape[1])])
pd_digits = pd.concat([pd_digits,
                       pd.Series(digits.target,
                                  name = 'target')],
                                  axis = 1)
DIGITS = oml.push(pd_digits)
print("Shape: ", DIGITS.shape)

paragraphs.title: Split data 80/20
paragraphs.text:
%python

splits = DIGITS.split(ratio=(.2, .8), use_hash = False)
print("Split lengths: ", [len(split) for split in splits])

msg.data: Split lengths:  [351, 1446]

paragraphs.title: Split data into 4 even samples
paragraphs.text:
%python

splits = DIGITS.split(ratio = (.25, .25, .25, .25), use_hash = False)
print("Split lengths: ", [len(split) for split in splits])

msg.data: Split lengths:  [432, 460, 451, 454]

paragraphs.title: Stratified sampling
paragraphs.text:
%python

splits = DIGITS.split(strata_cols=['target'])
print("Split lengths: ", [split.shape for split in splits])

paragraphs.title: Veryify stratified samples
Hash on target column
paragraphs.text:
%python

splits = DIGITS.split(hash_cols=['target'])
print("Split lengths: ", [split.shape for split in splits])

paragraphs.title: Verify hashing
Randomly split into 4 folds
paragraphs.text:
%python

folds = DIGITS.KFold(n_splits=4)

print("Split lengths: ", [(len(fold[0]), len(fold[1])) for fold in folds])

%md

Next, we explore the ***corr*** function. We construct a trivial, highly correlated DataFrame. First, verify that the correlation between column A and B is 1.

msg.data: Next, we explore the corr function. We construct a trivial, highly correlated DataFrame. First, verify that the correlation between column A and B is 1.

paragraphs.text:
%python

import pandas as pd

my_df2 = pd.DataFrame({'A': range(4), 'B': [2*i for i in range(4)]})
MY_DF2 = oml.push(my_df2)
MY_DF2

%python

MY_DF2.corr()

msg.data:
A  B
A  1  1
B  1  1

paragraphs.text:
%md

When using ***corr***, by default, 'skipna' is True.

msg.data: When using corr, by default, 'skipna' is True.

paragraphs.title: Modify data to alter correlation results
paragraphs.text:
%python

my_df3 = my_df2

my_df3.loc[2, 'A'] = 1.5

# Change an entry to NaN (not a number) to test the 'skipna' parameter in corr
my_df3.loc[1, 'B'] = None

# Push my_df3 to Oracle Database using the floating point column type 
# because NaNs cannot be used in Oracle numbers
MY_DF3 = oml.push(my_df3, oranumber=False)
MY_DF3

paragraphs.title: Default corr skipping missing values
paragraphs.text:
%python

MY_DF3.corr()

paragraphs.title: Not skipping missing values produces NaNs
paragraphs.text:
%python



MY_DF3.corr(skipna=False)

msg.data:
A    B
A  1.0  NaN
B  NaN  1.0

paragraphs.text:
%md

Next, explore the ***crosstab*** and ***pivot*** functions on a DataFrame relating gender, 
left or right handedness, and speed and accuracy on some task.

msg.data:
Next, explore the crosstab and pivot functions on a DataFrame relating gender,
left or right handedness, and speed and accuracy on some task.

paragraphs.title: Create demo data as temporary table
Find the categories that the most entries belonged to
paragraphs.text:
%python

MY_DF4.crosstab('GENDER', 'HAND').sort_values('count', ascending=False)

msg.data:
GENDER  HAND  count
0      F     R      5
1      M     L      2
2      M     R      2
3      F     L      1
4      M  None      1
5   None     R      1

paragraphs.title: For each gender and across entries, find ratio of entries with different hand values
paragraphs.text:
%python

MY_DF4.crosstab('GENDER', 'HAND', pivot = True, margins = True, normalize = 0)

paragraphs.title: Find the mean speed across all gender and hand combinations
paragraphs.text:
%python

MY_DF4.pivot_table('GENDER', 'HAND', 'SPEED')

msg.data:
GENDER  mean(SPEED)_(L)  mean(SPEED)_(R)  mean(SPEED)_(None)
0      F            34.10            40.78                 NaN
1      M            45.85            27.85                29.3
2   None              NaN            46.40                 NaN

paragraphs.title: Find the median vlaues for accuracy and speed by gender and hand
paragraphs.text:
%python

MY_DF4.pivot_table('GENDER', 'HAND', aggfunc = oml.DataFrame.median)

msg.data:
GENDER  median(ACCURACY)_(L)  median(ACCURACY)_(R)  median(ACCURACY)_(None)  median(SPEED)_(L)  median(SPEED)_(R)  median(SPEED)_(None)
0      F                  0.96                 0.870                      NaN              34.10              39.60                   NaN
1      M                  0.91                 0.925                     0.97              45.85              27.85                  29.3
2   None                   NaN                 0.890                      NaN                NaN              46.40                   NaN

paragraphs.title: Find the max and min speeds for every gender and hand combination and across all combinations
paragraphs.text:
%python

MY_DF4.pivot_table('GENDER', 'HAND', 'SPEED', 
               aggfunc = [oml.DataFrame.max, oml.DataFrame.min],
               margins = True)

msg.data:
GENDER  max(SPEED)_(L)  max(SPEED)_(R)  max(SPEED)_(None)  max(SPEED)_(All)  min(SPEED)_(L)  min(SPEED)_(R)  min(SPEED)_(None)  min(SPEED)_(All)
0    All            51.2            60.8               29.3              60.8            34.1            12.0               29.3              12.0
1      F            34.1            60.8                NaN              60.8            34.1            12.0                NaN              12.0
2      M            51.2            30.4               29.3              51.2            40.5            25.3               29.3              25.3
3   None             NaN            46.4                NaN              46.4             NaN            46.4                NaN              46.4

paragraphs.text:
%md
## Create new columns

Next, explore creating new columns using a simple shopping cart data set. Note, that using the transparency layer, all these computations occur in-database. Neither the input nor the result needs to be brought to the client Python engine.

msg.data:
Create new columns

Next, explore creating new columns using a simple shopping cart data set. Note, that using the transparency layer, all these computations occur in-database. Neither the input nor the result needs to be brought to the client Python engine.

paragraphs.title: Create demo data as temporary table
paragraphs.text:
%python

shopping_cart = pd.DataFrame({
  'Item_name': ['paper_towel', 'ground_pork', 'tofu', 'eggs',
                'pork_loin', 'whole_milk', 'egg_custard'],
  'Item_type': ['grocery', 'meat', 'grocery', 'dairy', 'meat',
                'dairy', 'bakery'],
  'Quantity': [1, 2.6, 4, 1, 1.9, 1, 1],
  'Unit_price': [1.19, 2.79, 0.99, 2.49, 3.19, 2.5, 3.99]
  })
CART = oml.push(shopping_cart)
CART

msg.data:
Item_name Item_type  Quantity  Unit_price
0  paper_towel   grocery       1.0        1.19
1  ground_pork      meat       2.6        2.79
2         tofu   grocery       4.0        0.99
3         eggs     dairy       1.0        2.49
4    pork_loin      meat       1.9        3.19
5   whole_milk     dairy       1.0        2.50
6  egg_custard    bakery       1.0        3.99

paragraphs.title: Create a column Price = Quantity * Unit_price
paragraphs.text:
%python


price = CART['Quantity']*(CART['Unit_price'])
print("Type: ", type(price))

CART = CART.concat({'Price': price.round(2)})

CART

msg.data:
Type:  <class 'oml.core.float.Float'>
     Item_name Item_type  Quantity  Unit_price  Price
0  paper_towel   grocery       1.0        1.19   1.19
1  ground_pork      meat       2.6        2.79   7.25
2         tofu   grocery       4.0        0.99   3.96
3         eggs     dairy       1.0        2.49   2.49
4    pork_loin      meat       1.9        3.19   6.06
5   whole_milk     dairy       1.0        2.50   2.50
6  egg_custard    bakery       1.0        3.99   3.99

paragraphs.title: Count the pattern 'egg' in the Item_name column
paragraphs.text:
%python

egg_pattern = CART['Item_name'].count_pattern('egg')
print("Type: ", type(egg_pattern))
CART.concat({'Egg_pattern': egg_pattern})

msg.data:
Type:  <class 'oml.core.float.Float'>
     Item_name Item_type  Quantity  Unit_price  Price  Egg_pattern
0  paper_towel   grocery       1.0        1.19   1.19            0
1  ground_pork      meat       2.6        2.79   7.25            0
2         tofu   grocery       4.0        0.99   3.96            0
3         eggs     dairy       1.0        2.49   2.49            1
4    pork_loin      meat       1.9        3.19   6.06            0
5   whole_milk     dairy       1.0        2.50   2.50            0
6  egg_custard    bakery       1.0        3.99   3.99            1

paragraphs.title: Find the start index of substring 'pork' in the Item_name column
paragraphs.text:
%python

pork_startInd = CART['Item_name'].find('pork')
print("Type: ", type(pork_startInd))
CART.concat({'Pork_startInd': pork_startInd})

msg.data:
Type:  <class 'oml.core.float.Float'>
     Item_name Item_type  Quantity  Unit_price  Price  Pork_startInd

paragraphs.title: Use a few other function to modify the Price column
paragraphs.text:
%python

print("Ceiling: ", CART['Price'].ceil())
print("Floor: ", CART['Price'].floor())
print("Exponential: ", CART['Price'].exp().round(3))
print("logarithm: ", CART['Price'].log().round(3))
print("Square Root: ", CART['Price'].sqrt().round(3))

%md

Next, using a modified version of the *iris* data set, explore ***sort_values*** and ***tail*** functions.

We modify the dataset by replacing a few entries with NaNs to test how the ***na_position*** parameter works in the ***sort_values*** method.

msg.data:
Next, using a modified version of the iris data set, explore sort_values and tail functions.

We modify the dataset by replacing a few entries with NaNs to test how the na_position parameter works in the sort_values method.

paragraphs.title: Create demo data as temporary table
paragraphs.text:
%python

from sklearn.datasets import load_iris
import pandas as pd

iris = load_iris()

x = pd.DataFrame(iris.data, columns = ['Sepal_Length', 'Sepal_Width',
                                       'Petal_Length', 'Petal_Width'])
y = pd.DataFrame(list(map(lambda x: {0: 'setosa', 1: 'versicolor',
                                     2:'virginica'}[x], iris.target)), 
                 columns = ['SPECIES'])
                   
x['Sepal_Width'].replace({3.5: None}, inplace=True)
x['Petal_Length'].replace({1.5: None}, inplace=True)
x['Petal_Width'].replace({2.3: None}, inplace=True)

iris_df = pd.concat([x, y], axis=1)
IRIS2 = oml.push(iris_df)

paragraphs.title: Sort data set first by Sepal_Length then by Sepal_Width in descending order
paragraphs.text:
%python

IRIS2.sort_values(by = ['Sepal_Length', 'Sepal_Width'], ascending=False).head(8)

msg.data:
Sepal_Length  Sepal_Width  Petal_Length  Petal_Width    SPECIES
0           7.9          3.8           6.4          2.0  virginica
1           7.7          3.8           6.7          2.2  virginica
2           7.7          3.0           6.1          NaN  virginica
3           7.7          2.8           6.7          2.0  virginica
4           7.7          2.6           6.9          NaN  virginica
5           7.6          3.0           6.6          2.1  virginica
6           7.4          2.8           6.1          1.9  virginica
7           7.3          2.9           6.3          1.8  virginica

paragraphs.title: Display last 5 rows of the data set
paragraphs.text:
%python

IRIS2.tail()

msg.data:
Sepal_Length  Sepal_Width  Petal_Length  Petal_Width    SPECIES
0           7.9          3.8           6.4          2.0  virginica
1           7.6          3.0           6.6          2.1  virginica
2           7.7          2.8           6.7          2.0  virginica
3           7.7          3.8           6.7          2.2  virginica
4           7.7          2.6           6.9          NaN  virginica

paragraphs.title: Sort last 5 rows of the iris data set by Petal_Length then by Petal_Width
paragraphs.text:
%python

IRIS2.tail().sort_values(by = ['Petal_Length', 'Petal_Width'], na_position = 'last')

msg.data:
Sepal_Length  Sepal_Width  Petal_Length  Petal_Width    SPECIES
0           7.9          3.8           6.4          2.0  virginica
1           7.6          3.0           6.6          2.1  virginica
2           7.7          2.8           6.7          2.0  virginica
3           7.7          3.8           6.7          2.2  virginica
4           7.7          2.6           6.9          NaN  virginica

paragraphs.text:
%md

Next, we explore column creation/renaming, describing data statistics, and computing a variety of statistics.

msg.data: Next, we explore column creation/renaming, describing data statistics, and computing a variety of statistics.

paragraphs.title: Create demo data as temporary table
paragraphs.text:
%python

my_df4 = pd.DataFrame({'numeric_col': [1, 1.4, -4, 3.145, 5, None],
                       'string_col' : [None, None, 'a', 'a', 'a', 'b'],
                       'bytes_col'  : [b'a', b'b', b'c', b'c', b'd', b'e']})

MY_DF4 = oml.push(my_df4, dbtypes = {'numeric_col': 'BINARY_DOUBLE',
                                     'string_col':'CHAR(1)', 
                                     'bytes_col':'RAW(1)'})
MY_DF4

msg.data:
numeric_col string_col bytes_col
0        1.000       None      b'a'
1        1.400       None      b'b'
2       -4.000          a      b'c'
3        3.145          a      b'c'
4        5.000          a      b'd'
5          NaN          b      b'e'

paragraphs.title: Combine a Boolean column with MY_DF4
paragraphs.text:
%python

oml_bool = MY_DF4['numeric_col'] > 3

MY_DF4 = MY_DF4.concat(oml_bool)
MY_DF4.rename({'COL4':'boolean_col'})

msg.data:
numeric_col string_col bytes_col  boolean_col
0        1.000       None      b'a'        False
1        1.400       None      b'b'        False
2       -4.000          a      b'c'        False
3        3.145          a      b'c'         True
4        5.000          a      b'd'         True
5          NaN          b      b'e'         True

paragraphs.text:
%md

Use the describe function to compute a variety of statistics on all columns. Then, exclude the Float columns.

msg.data: Use the describe function to compute a variety of statistics on all columns. Then, exclude the Float columns.

paragraphs.text:
%python

MY_DF4.describe(include='all')

numeric_col string_col bytes_col boolean_col
count      5.000000          4         6           6
unique          NaN          2         5           2
top             NaN          a      b'c'       False
freq            NaN          3         2           3
mean       1.309000        NaN       NaN         NaN
std        3.364655        NaN       NaN         NaN

25%        1.000000        NaN       NaN         NaN
50%        1.400000        NaN       NaN         NaN

max        5.000000        NaN       NaN         NaN

MY_DF4.describe(exclude=[oml.Float])

count           4         6           6
unique          2         5           2
top             a      b'c'       False
freq            3         2           3

paragraphs.title: Compute the sum of values in each Float or Boolean column
paragraphs.text:
%python

MY_DF4.sum()

numeric_col    6.545
boolean_col    3.000
dtype: float64

paragraphs.text:
%md

Find the cumulative sum of values in each Float or Boolean column after MY_DF4 is sorted by the bytes column in descending order. Then, compute skew, median, and kurtosis for float columns.

msg.data: Find the cumulative sum of values in each Float or Boolean column after MY_DF4 is sorted by the bytes column in descending order. Then, compute skew, median, and kurtosis for float columns.

paragraphs.title: Compute cummulate sum
paragraphs.text:
%python

MY_DF4.cumsum(by = 'bytes_col', ascending = False)

paragraphs.title: Compute select statistics
paragraphs.text:
%python

print(MY_DF4.skew())
print(MY_DF4.median())
print(MY_DF4.kurtosis())

msg.data:
numeric_col   -0.683838
dtype: float64
numeric_col    1.4
dtype: float64
numeric_col   -0.582684
dtype: float64

paragraphs.text:
%md

Next, use the overloaded ***boxplot*** and ***hist*** functions using the *wine* data set. The statistics supporting these plots are computed in-database, so transfer of data or client side memory limitations are avoided.

msg.data: Next, use the overloaded boxplot and hist functions using the wine data set. The statistics supporting these plots are computed in-database, so transfer of data or client side memory limitations are avoided.

paragraphs.title: Boxplot of select columns
paragraphs.text:
%python

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
from sklearn.datasets import load_wine

wine = load_wine()
wine_data = pd.DataFrame(wine.data, columns = wine.feature_names)
WINE = oml.push(wine_data)

oml.graphics.boxplot(WINE[:,8:12], showmeans=True, 
                     meanline=True, patch_artist=True, 
                     labels=WINE.columns[8:12])
plt.title('Distribution of Wine Attributes')
plt.show()

paragraphs.title: Histogram of 'proline content'
paragraphs.text:
%python

oml.graphics.hist(WINE['proline'], bins=10, color='red',
                  linestyle='solid', edgecolor='black')
plt.title('Proline content in Wine')
plt.xlabel('proline content')
plt.ylabel('# of wine instances')
plt.show()

%md

# End of Script

msg.data: End of Script
